text: I know favorite games often have a lot to do with when you played them and your mindset and what was going on at the time. Â But OoT came out my senior year of highschool and was one of my last solid solo gaming experiences for a while (i played MGS a year later after it was out that too), after that I had college roomates and was gaming, but a lot more multiplayer and with other people around. Â This song, the level, the game, its not my favorite zelda, but possibly my single favorite dungeon in any zelda game.

author: LinkMarioSamus

text: I wonder where this game will be in 500 years, do you think the people of the future will still know about it, or maybe in the future there will be a history class where you learn about old entertainment from the past, who knows. it trips me out to think about, because even if someone owned a copy of Zelda that was 500 years old, there would be no way to play it, in the future they probably wouldn't still have A/V plugins on their tvs.
author: JordanMeAwesome

text: JordanMeAwesome I've thought a little bit about how some classic entertainment will age. OOT is not That old, relatively speaking. But in terms of video games, it's getting "old". Electronics and electronic entertainment ages fast I guess. Just the way it is. In 500 years, I should hope that this game will still be remembered. It'll still be fun to play I'll bet. Good games never die. Same with music, movies, TV, etc. But subjective nonetheless. I'm still betting it'll hold it's own no matter how much time may pass.

author: Joseph Pannone

text: The moment I stepped into the front entrance of the Forest Temple and this music started playing, I knew that the game was telling me that happy play time was over and now was the time to get serious. There's something serene and mysterious, yet there's a hint of the sinister here that had me thoroughly creeped out the entire dungeon. Not to mention the first encounter with those wall/floor masters... No other Zelda monster has ever scared me more than those have.

text: @Zeldawii2010 Are you kidding? The Nintendo 64 is just barely over 10 years old. What's REALLY impressive is that there's an entire culture based around the EARLY gaming consoles, like the Atari 2600 and the NES. It's hard to say you can "reminisce" about something that isn't very old... You gotta figure, it was honestly the last big step in gaming, with the jump to 3D and all.

Desert Temple and Fire Temple were my favorite.
